narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: It was a good introduction to sociology, and also allowed me to build a knowledge base of the facts regarding poverty and poverty alleviation in the US.

I learned so much from this course. It offers concrete knowledge for what a lot of us know to be abstractly true about race and economic inequality in the US, which is incredibly useful and eye-opening. Having Professor O'Brien as a professor, with this material in particular, is the type of combination that can change your undergraduate or future plans.
Knowledge of trends in inequalities in the U.S. and a baseline introduction to the potential causes of those inequalities and what is currently bieng (and has historically been) done to address them.
so many concrete facts about inequality in today's economy and society
This course taught me to ingest information and know more about America as a whole. I think this information should be known by all American adults to allow more perspective and compassion.
This course was an AMAZING introductory course in understanding inequality and mobility through the lens of social policy.
I learned about poverty and its complex impact on different parts of American society.
one of the best classes at yale

Taking this course, I learned a lot of facts about different measures of society and economic mobility. This course was definitely heavily on the side of learning the "what" rather than the "why," having us learn about different taxation systems, policy programs, poverty rates, and trends across the country.

I learned so much in this course!!!! I learned a ton about trends and systems of economic inequality and social mobility. All of the material is super duper relevant and simply important to know as someone living in the US. It's really an amazing foundational course. You learn about all different factors that contribute to poverty and inequality, including social policy and taxes. The workload is also super chill; you have weekly response memos (low stakes), a midterm exam (one page double sided very straight forward if you've been paying attention) and midterm paper about a cool sociologist of your choice, and finally the final which was also just one paper with a bunch of the same questions from the midterm. And Professor O'Brien is super energetic and passionate about the material and very friendly in office hours. Do yourself a favor and take this course!
Learned a lot more about trends in inequality in the US
overview of various policy/demographic trends, social programs, tax policy, and methods at studying and combating inequality
I developed my knowledge of the sociological trends and policies that mark the U.S.
I learned a lot about the societal constructs that perpetuate inequality.
This was an amazing course! The many statistics presented gave me a lot of knowledge about inequality, poverty, and mobility in the U.S.

General overview of what drives inequality in the United States and how inequality exist in the United States, including education, welfare policy, incarceration, social and economic mobility, labor markets, etc.
I really enjoyed this class and learned a lot!
SO MUCH KNOWLEDGE OF THE IMPORTANT SOCIAL HISTORY OF AMERICA!
a greater general understanding of societal structures & inequalities
You learn so much in the class!! You will leave knowing the past and current state of many important issues about US inequality and mobility.
Inequality across many topics
I learned about the intricacies of inequality, poverty, taxation, the criminal justice system etc. and public policy that has been created to ameliorate or further exacerbate these issues
In this course, I learned about the state of poverty and inequalities since about 1940. Also, learned about policy at the state and federal level.
Sociology

This course provided such a good overview to inequality in the US. I learned a bit about most major determinants of quality of life. The course really changed my perspective on much of how the US functions.
I learned so much about trends and factors in social mobility, tax policy, economic and racial inequality and beyond.

You learn extensively about the institutions that generate the socioeconomic inequality that we see today. There is a strong emphasis on empirical analysis  -- you don't learn any theory (rare W at Yale), you just look at what the real-world data shows. You won't learn much about policy redresses or the reasons why those institutions are in place / why they generate inequality. But you learn a lot about inequality, mobility, crime, health, taxes, social policy, labor markets, marriage/family, poverty, etc.
an overview of many topics of inequality, learned lots about economic/welfare policies in the US

This course helped me develop a better understanding of how inequality measurement and recent trends. Often poverty, unemployment, and single parenthood statistics are given in the news as objective fact, but this course helped me understand how these numbers are created and how they can be best used while acknowledging their limitations. I also learned some entirely new statistics that reframed my perception of how people interact with labor markets and how family structure has been changing.
Super helpful understanding of a lot of important trends and policies in the United States.
I gained a solid understanding of current American economic policies and structure through facts and statistics I've not been exposed to before.

I learned about various social determinants and measures of inequality and social mobility in the U.S., past and present, as well as the different public policies that address and shape these issues. I learned how social demographers approach these topics, and how to analyze the relationship between empirical research and political interventions.

- topics included: labor markets, social policy, incarceration, the family, tax policy, poverty, and so much more... (so so much valuable information!)
- looked at data and graphs and applied these to what we were learning
- I learned so much about our country and world that I believe everyone should be aware of, some things I had heard of but not fully understood
- wrote a paper on one sociologist and learned to summarize their work
So much about  social trends in the US, basics about US social policy. Super helpful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One of the few well balanced classes at Yale where you can absorb a ton of information without feeling overwhelmed by the amount of reading or weekly sections. I loved how engaged my TA and Rourke were throughout section and lecture  genuinely a class I looked forward to going to every week.
The professor had a contagious energy and a genuine passion for his work. No better way to begin the week/the day than with this class.

A major strength of this course is Professor O'Brien. He is unbelievably knowledgable, passionate, honest, and kind. He cares about his students as people and handles the course material with so much thoughtfulness. Another strength is the approach of the course, which focuses on important trends in different areas of social life. This format takes some getting used to and can at times feel a bit repetitive in class but is ultimately really useful knowledge that will definitely stick. The only major weakness was the weekly reading responses, which were simply not formatted to facilitate learning; they were too long to make it feasible for students to read each other's, and often difficult to write because of the length. If these can be re-imagined to be a bit more critical and shorter in length I would have no complaints about the class.

Everything is a strength! The content, the engaging and supportive professor and TFs, discussion section, the exam structure. Its all manageable, interesting, and provocative. Would recommend to anyone looking for an introduction to inequality and social policy.
only strengths. best class I've taken at Yale.
Rourke is the best teacher I have had at Yale and he engages the class so so so well

The course had a really good balance between ensuring to provide a foundational understanding of topics, whilst still expanding on and engaging with important debates/contentions that arise. I feel like the style of the lectures were perfect and Professor O'Brien was, quiet honestly, a PHENOMENAL instructor. I wish the discussion sections had a bit more structure.
All strengths. O'Brien is extremely enthusiastic about the material and goes through a lot of content in just one class but in a concise, and easy-to-understand crash-course style.

Weaknesses: no emphasis on the "why"
Strengths: everything else. The material was super interesting, Rourke did an awesome job at covering a range of topics, and Rourke himself is the biggest strength

strengths: super interesting and important material for literally everyone to know, light workload, awesome professor

weaknesses: very fast pace and you don't spend much time on any one particular topic so you only get an overview of topics with lots of holes to be filled in later hopefully!
Its a lot of material but very fair tests!

The strength is Rourkes contagious passion and incredible knowledge of the content. Every lecture is both informative and interesting. It is the best class I have taken so far, I dont see any weaknesses.

strengths - Prof. O' Brien is very enthusiastic and helpful, he is super passionate about the course content and is always willing to make time for students.
weaknesses - none
Rourke is great! I don't think much could be improved. I learned much more in this course than the other courses I took this semester, and the grading is very fair.

Strengths - O'Brien as a professor; readings were very interesting and allowed us to delve deeper into particular topics; lectures were cohesive and contained a lot of important information without being overwhelming; exams were easy, fair, and straightforward
Weaknesses - None everyone should take this course and has something to learn from it!
I learned a lot about misconceptions and important statistics on social inequality which helped give me important context when thinking about social policy
it's amazing take it
o'brien is a very engaging and delightful professor

Strengths: Covers a wide range of topics; digestible information; such an engaged prof 

Weaknesses: I know theres a lot of info to cover but lectures sometimes feel a bit rushed

The section structure was a good place to discuss ideas and have students of different backgrounds discuss their ideas of inequality.
Weaknesses: no recorded lectures

strengths: straight forward but deep, meaningful topic, very good lecturer, readings supplement lectures, assignments fair

weaknesses: discussion sections didnt feel incredibly supplementary/necessary

Strengths - always offers interesting reads and lectures. Professor is the absolute best. 
Weakness - due to time limits, there are topics that I would have liked to learn more about but couldn't in this class. Luckily, there are classes that do dive deeper into most topics in the class.
Really loved the professor and my section TA.
Strengths: everything. A very organized, well-taught course. I was very engaged and learned a lot. The exams were easy, but I felt like this was the class I learned the most in.
The course is incredibly stimulating and a very reasonable work load.

The information you get from this course is very valuable in shaping how you see the world. Without a doubt, understanding what's actually going on in our societal infrastructure and its effects on inequality really influences how you read the news, how you orient your career, etc. It's awesome that this course focuses a lot on real-world outcomes, and I really appreciate how much of the information on the slides was conveyed through charts and graphs. I appreciated that only information that you needed to know was on the slides -- Professor O'Brien never put extraneous information there. Sections should have some more structure and objectives. I rarely got much out of section. I think the sociology essay seemed a bit like busy work -- I didn't really get much out of it either; it just felt like a longer reading response.
really informative course, great instructor, very interesting topic

Professor O'Brien presented all the material in a way that was both interesting and informative. Coursetime was well divided between subjects, and even though there wasn't enough time to go in-depth on everything, all topics got a fair share.
Overall an amazing course. The work was fairly easy but the material was very engaging and the weekly readings built very helpfully on the course. Rourke is an amazing lecturer!

Strength: the course information and focuses were well-selected; I never felt like the information was unnecessary or inapplicable to current policy or society. Professor O'Brien was energetic and detail-oriented. Weakness: There was so much content packed into each lesson that there was not much room for questions or to allow ideas to set in before moving straight into the next topic.

The strengths of this course are that: 1) the weekly response memos force you to engage with the assigned readings, which helps me to make the most of lectures. 2) the readings are more diverse medium than I've experienced with other classes, I liked that there were articles as well as book chapters. 3) testing is extremely fair and what we learn and have to memorize is actually useful information for us to know more about how the US is run.

I can't really think of any weaknesses except that lectures move kind of quickly.

This course did a great job at covering diverse topics on inequality and mobility as understood by sociologists and other social scientists. It was well organized, and revealed important social trends over time as well as the influences of various social and environmental factors. The lectures were especially informative. One area for improvement could be in the structuring of discussion section meetings. I think sections could be organized to better supplement material covered in lecture, by having a more consistent format.

strengths:
- the professor
- the TA's
- the structure of the class
- organization
- homework and assignments 

weaknesses: 
- none
Strenghts:  Rourke O'Brien is so committed to teaching and so passionate about the content. You will be inspired to understand inequality and be motivated to change current trends and policies.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For anyone with a remote interest in sociology, policy, or inequality in the US, this class will give you the fundamental building blocks to thinking about factors that shape any large policy or economic issue in the US.
I would, especially those who care about US public policy and want to understand it with nuance.
Absolutely! It is unlike any other sociology course I have taken at Yale, the material and professor are amazing, and I am leaving feeling like I learned truly useful knowledge.
absolutely. this course will help you understand how neighborhoods, families, crime, schools, taxation, social policy, and just about everything else is connected in telling the story of inequality
Yes! The discussions evoked from the material both inside and outside of class are worth it and Rourke is an execelent professor you will want to have taken a class with.
YES!!! BEST CLASS AT YALE. PROFESSOR IS AMAZING.
I would and have recommended this course to just about every person I know. You learn more about the world but the class is fun and the assignments arent painful.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, especially with Professor O'Brien! Professor O'Brien, and all of the TAs, were fantastic. Lectures were always incredibly engaging and I left this course actually learning things about inequality and mobility in the United States.
If you are interested in learning about poverty in America, yes!
Rourke is one of the best professors at this school
Yes! If you want an introduction to sociology and economic mobility, this is the class for you!

Absolutely!!! The workload is very light and straightforward. The professor and TFs are all awesome people doing amazing work. The information is pertinent to know. The class is very engaging just to listen to. I can't stress enough how important it is to know the material that's taught in this course!
Yes! Rourke is a great professor and the material was very interesting
Yes! Incredible to understand the welfare policy situation in the United States and Rourke is a fantastic lecturer.
Yes, absolutely. Every student would benefit from this course.
Definitely would
If you want a fun, engaging course that teaches you very applicable sociology and doesn't take much of your time, 1000% choose this.
Definitely! Any class with Rourke is great.

Yes absolutely! Even if you are or think you are familiar with some of these topics, everyone has something to gain from this course. The content is incredibly important and the lectures gave great, concise information and introductions on them while the readings allowed for different lenses to come through. This is one of my favorite classes I have taken at Yale.
Yes! One of the best classes at Yale
YES YES YES YES
yeah, mostly so you can get to take a class with o'brien

Everyone should take this course to understand the state of the world and how we got to where we are!! Know that the course is mainly fact based and doesnt provide time for analysis on the why. However, the professor is very upfront about that.
Yes you learn a lot of info that you wouldnt know otherwise

This is an incredible way to get an overview of inequality, poverty, and public policy in the United States. Easy to learn because naturally interesting and Rourke facilitates a positive and nurturing learning environment
Yes! This has been one of my favorite classes, and changed my career trajectory.

Yes; this is a fantastic intro course to inequality, poverty, mobility, and public policy. It is genuinely focused on learning and not a workload so it was a non-stressful fifth credit that has shaped what I want to do with my career. Also, Prof. O'Brien is excellent and loves what he teaches.

Absolutely. This course is not too much work, but it is incredibly engaging and rewarding. Rourke is a phenomenal professor and is super passionate about everything he teaches. One of the best courses I've taken at Yale
Absolutely, I took this class on a whim and it was one of my favorites. Everyday class was engaging and he made very full topics ie tax policy interesting.

Take it. Just take the class -- if you can't, just audit and attend lectures. Learn the information. Be an informed citizen of the world. You will get a lot more out of this course if you are familiar with some statistical techniques -- by no means do you need it, but it just helps you appreciate how you've arrived at the data that you see.
Yes, very good overview of the state of inequality in the US, very interesting lectures, awesome instructor
Yes, it's a great course for anyone interested in the topic, and appeals as both an introduction to and a expansion on the topic.
Yes! Very much. Loved taking this.

Absolutely! Lots of valuable information, and it's grounded in facts and figures rather than theory or conceptual ideas---very important for understanding how American politics and society operates especially if you're interested in research or public policy work.

I would!!!! This class was better than I could have thought, one of my favorites at Yale so far. Professor O'Brien is amazing and his passion alone makes the content so interesting. If you have any interest in the course title at all... take it!!!

YES! PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS! 1000%. This is the kind of course every student needs to take before graduating. Professor O'Brien is an incredible professor and his passion for the subject will make you passionate about it too.

I would recommend this course to all students, because it provides essential insights into the dynamics of the American economy and its impact on groups and individuals. Relevant to any studying social sciences (especially those interested in economics or public policy), but more broadly important knowledge as citizens of the U.S. or, through comparison, other nations.

Yes! I would 100% recommend this course. It was clearly taught, and I learned so many important facts about our world that relate to every person. I also enjoyed going to lectures and sections. This is a very relevant and needed class to take.

Absolutely. Everyone needs to take a socio class with Rourke. He is magnetic with his commitment to students and sociology. If you want to get a basic understanding for US social trends, programs, policies, how inequality really shapes up in our country, and what one can do about it, this is totally the class. And again, Rourke, with his excitement every. single. day. !!
